Abstract: Touch Kea, 75, barber to King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, recalls horrors of Khmer Rouge genocide in late 1970's, while Touch Sopharath, a 19-year-old granddaugher of his and a law student, looks forward to a normal life; chronology of Cambodian history since 1953 (M)
Snippet: Touch Kea, 75, barber to King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, recalls horrors of Khmer Rouge genocide in late 1970's, while Touch Sopharath, a 19-year-old granddaugher of his and a law student, looks forward to a normal life; chronology of Cambodian...
LeadParagraph: Few countries suffered as deeply as Cambodia over the last half-century. The tiny, beautiful Southeast Asian land was a battleground among the great powers and the scene of hugely destructive American bombing during the Vietnam War. Then its own internal demons rose from within its people's brutalized psyche. Cambodia became the scene of horrific mass killings by the radical communist Khmer Rouge, who from 1975 to 1979 took the lives of as many as one-fourth of the population of eight million.

Headline.Main: 'We Just Waited for Our Moment to Be Killed'
Headline.PrintHeadline: REFLECTIONS: CAMBODIA; 'We Just Waited for Our Moment to Be Killed'
